Everyday Physics","description":"

This is a fully online course that looks at everyday applications of physics. No prior physics knowledge is required. The course will look at the physics behind several everyday phenomena. Physics topics addressed in this course include thermodynamics, properties of fluids, basic mechanics, electricity and magnetism, waves, nuclear physics, quantum physics, optics and astronomy. Basic experimental methods will be covered through simulations and simple experiments that can be conducted at home. The course will make use of Physclips. The course would form a good basic physics knowledge for students studying life sciences, medicine and business and for those planning to sit the Gamsat exam. This is a quantitative course using algebra and trigonometry but not calculus.

contentlets.description: This is a fully online course that looks at everyday applications of physics. No prior physics knowledge is required. The course will look at the physics behind several everyday phenomena. Physics topics addressed in this course include thermodynamics, properties of fluids, basic mechanics, electricity and magnetism, waves, nuclear physics, quantum physics, optics and astronomy. Basic experimental methods will be covered through simulations and simple experiments that can be conducted at home. The course will make use of Physclips. The course would form a good basic physics knowledge for students studying life sciences, medicine and business and for those planning to sit the Gamsat exam. This is a quantitative course using algebra and trigonometry but not calculus.

Fundamentals of Physics","description":"

This is an introductory level course in physics for students from all disciplines.The course will cover the methods of Physics, including the following topics: the description of motion; forces and momentum; the dynamics of particles; kinetic and potential energy; the conservation of energy; temperature and thermal equilibrium; specific and latent heat; thermal energy; fluids and fluid flow; oscillations and simple harmonic motion; waves, wave reflection, refraction and interference; the wave nature of light; electric fields and charge; electric potential and energy; electric currents; magnetism; electromagnetic induction and Faraday'??s law; early quantum theory and models of the atom; nuclear physics and radioactivity; nuclear energy.


Note: There is no Assumed Knowledge for this course. It also serves as a suitable introduction to Physics for students whose Program requires them to take PHYS1121 or PHYS1131 but who do not have the recommended level of Assumed Knowledge for these courses.

contentlets.description:
This is an introductory level course in physics for students from all disciplines.The course will cover the methods of Physics, including the following topics: the description of motion; forces and momentum; the dynamics of particles; kinetic and potential energy; the conservation of energy; temperature and thermal equilibrium; specific and latent heat; thermal energy; fluids and fluid flow; oscillations and simple harmonic motion; waves, wave reflection, refraction and interference; the wave nature of light; electric fields and charge; electric potential and energy; electric currents; magnetism; electromagnetic induction and Faraday'??s law; early quantum theory and models of the atom; nuclear physics and radioactivity; nuclear energy.

Note: There is no Assumed Knowledge for this course. It also serves as a suitable introduction to Physics for students whose Program requires them to take PHYS1121 or PHYS1131 but who do not have the recommended level of Assumed Knowledge for these courses.

Physics 1A","description":"

This course provides an introduction to Physics. It is a calculus based course. The course is examined at two levels, with Physics 1A being the lower of the two levels.

Mechanics: particle kinematics in one dimension, motion in two and three dimensions, particle dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation

Thermal physics: temperature, kinetic theory and the ideal gas, heat and the first law of thermodynamics.

Waves: oscillations, wave motion, sound waves.

Assumed Knowledge : HSC Physics and Mathematics Extension 1 or equivalent. If you have not reached this level of physics and mathematics you may wish to take PHYS1111 Fundamentals of Physics before enrolling in this course.

One quarter of the lab mark comes form pre-laboratory quizzes that the students complete online before the laboratory. Students receive feedback as they submit their answers. Students are marked by demonstrators in the lab as they complete each of the experiments.

Students will complete regular online quizzes drawn from a large question bank at home during semester with feedback programmed into the quizzes. This will form 10% of their mark. Twice during the semester students will take an invigilated online quiz drawn from the same question bank (with randomized variables). Each of these will form 10% of the total mark for the course.

contentlets.description:
This course provides an introduction to Physics. It is a calculus based course. The course is examined at two levels, with Physics 1A being the lower of the two levels.

Mechanics: particle kinematics in one dimension, motion in two and three dimensions, particle dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation

Thermal physics: temperature, kinetic theory and the ideal gas, heat and the first law of thermodynamics.

Waves: oscillations, wave motion, sound waves.

Assumed Knowledge : HSC Physics and Mathematics Extension 1 or equivalent. If you have not reached this level of physics and mathematics you may wish to take PHYS1111 Fundamentals of Physics before enrolling in this course.

Higher Physics 1A","description":"

This course provides an introduction to Physics. It is a calculus based course. The course is examined at two levels, with Higher Physics 1A being the higher of the two levels. While the same content is covered as Physics 1A, Higher Physics 1A features more advanced assessment.

Mechanics: particle kinematics in one dimension, motion in two and three dimensions, particle dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation

Thermal physics: temperature, kinetic theory and the ideal gas, heat and the first law of thermodynamics.

Waves: oscillations, wave motion, sound waves.

Assumed Knowledge : HSC Physics and Mathematics Extension 1 or equivalent. If you have not reached this level of physics and mathematics you may wish to take PHYS1111 Fundamentals of Physics before enrolling in this course. Students planning on taking Physics 1B should take MATH1131/1141/1151 as the corequisite for PHYS1131.

Students will complete regular online quizzes drawn from a large question bank at home during semester with feedback programmed into the quizzes. This will form 10% of their mark. Twice during the semester students will take an invigilated online quiz drawn from the same question bank (with randomized variables). Each of these will form 10% of the total mark for the course.

contentlets.description:
This course provides an introduction to Physics. It is a calculus based course. The course is examined at two levels, with Higher Physics 1A being the higher of the two levels. While the same content is covered as Physics 1A, Higher Physics 1A features more advanced assessment.

Mechanics: particle kinematics in one dimension, motion in two and three dimensions, particle dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation

Thermal physics: temperature, kinetic theory and the ideal gas, heat and the first law of thermodynamics.

Waves: oscillations, wave motion, sound waves.

Assumed Knowledge : HSC Physics and Mathematics Extension 1 or equivalent. If you have not reached this level of physics and mathematics you may wish to take PHYS1111 Fundamentals of Physics before enrolling in this course. Students planning on taking Physics 1B should take MATH1131/1141/1151 as the corequisite for PHYS1131.

Higher Physics 1A (Special)","description":"

This course provides an introduction to Physics. It is a calculus based course. The lecture content covered in this course is the same as Physics 1A and  Higher Physics 1A. Higher Physics 1A (Special) features more advanced assessment, including separate tutorial and laboratory classes. This course is aimed at students who are considering undertaking a science or advanced science degree and majoring in physics or physical science.
Mechanics: particle kinematics in one dimension, motion in two and three dimensions, particle dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation.
Thermal physics: temperature, kinetic theory and the ideal gas, heat and the first law of thermodynamics.
Waves: oscillations, wave motion, sound waves.

Twice during the semester students will take an invigilated online quiz drawn from the same question bank (with randomized variables). Each of these will form 10% of the total mark for the course.

Physics 1A (Aviation)","description":"

This is an introductory level course on physics for students in aviation.The course will cover the methods of Physics, including the following topics: the description of motion; forces and momentum; the dynamics of particles; kinetic and potential energy; the conservation of energy; temperature and thermal equilibrium; specific and latent heat; thermal energy; fluids and fluid flow; oscillations and simple harmonic motion; waves, wave reflection, refraction and interference; the wave nature of light; electric fields and charge; electric potential and energy; electric currents; magnetism; electromagnetic induction and Faraday'??s law; early quantum theory and models of the atom; nuclear physics and radioactivity; nuclear energy.


Note: There is no Assumed Knowledge for this course

contentlets.description:
This is an introductory level course on physics for students in aviation.The course will cover the methods of Physics, including the following topics: the description of motion; forces and momentum; the dynamics of particles; kinetic and potential energy; the conservation of energy; temperature and thermal equilibrium; specific and latent heat; thermal energy; fluids and fluid flow; oscillations and simple harmonic motion; waves, wave reflection, refraction and interference; the wave nature of light; electric fields and charge; electric potential and energy; electric currents; magnetism; electromagnetic induction and Faraday'??s law; early quantum theory and models of the atom; nuclear physics and radioactivity; nuclear energy.

Note: There is no Assumed Knowledge for this course

The Search for Life Elsewhere in the Universe","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/GENS4014","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"GENS4014","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"PHYS1160 - Introduction to Astronomy","description":"

Introduction to Astronomy and the search for life elsewhere.This course provides a broad overview of Astronomy and our place in the Cosmos. It covers the solar system and its exploration, stars, galaxies and cosmology, the Earth as a habitable planet and the search for life elsewhere in the universe. The course is delivered wholly on the internet through  Moodle. The course is suitable as an introductory course for science students or as a general education course for non-scientists.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"387770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961996","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"18","description":"

Students will write a 1500-2000 word essay on a topic chosen from a range of suggested topics. These are due in week 6, and will be marked based on the degree of understanding of the topic, the quality and depth of research, clarity of presentation, and originality of the coverage of the topic. Feedback will be provided within two weeks of the submission date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3c7770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a87770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc7770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"187770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"24","description":"

Student will complete a 90-minute online test with a mix of multiple-choice and multiple-answer questions. This will be on the course website in Moodle and will be due before the end of the teaching period. The test will cover materials taught in the course. Marking is automatic and results and feedback will be released after all students have completed the test.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a87770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"507770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96195c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Group Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"26","description":"

Students will contribute to four online discussions centred around Modules 1, 2, 3, and 4/5 of the course. These contributions are due in Weeks 3, 5, 7, and 9 respectively. The contributions will be graded based on the quality of the posts and the marks account for 16% of the total mark for the course. Feedback will be provided within a week of submission.

In addition, students will submit by Week 10 what they consider to be their best two contributions to the discussion forum. These will be marked based on the amount of research, clarity of presentation and understanding of the topics. The mark will account for 10% of the total mark for the course.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3c7770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"987770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"32","description":"

There are 20 course activities (interactive tutorials) associated with the online lessons. Students will complete these activities, which test the students on the materials covered in the lessons and may involve further research in the textbook or on the internet. These activities are graded and feedback is immediate. All activities must be completed by the end of the teaching period.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"247770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a87770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc7770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e07770bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PHYS1160.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PHYS1200","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHYS1200 - Step into Research","description":"

PHYS1200 is a one-term research project for first-year students.  Students choose from a set of available supervisors and projects, work regularly in the research groups, and present their results to a group of peers and researchers. This course serves as an entry point into physics research for motivated students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1c67d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will conduct a research project under the supervision of a member of the academic staff.  The project may involve conducting experiments in the laboratory, analysis of data from observations, theoretical calculations, or some combination of the above. At the end of the project, a mark will be given by their supervisor on their research performance.  Some characteristics the supervisor may wish to assess include: the student's approach to the problem, preparatory reading, planning of experimental work, design of apparatus, independence, execution of the research, diligence, understanding of the principles, experimental technique, judgment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8c67d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c867d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0067d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will give a 5-minute talk each at the end of the teaching term (around Week 10) about their research project, including aims, a brief description of the methodology, results, and conclusions.  The presentation will be marked based on the clarity of explanation of the project aims, quality of the presentation, relevance of the results, and delivery.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1867d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf57d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will submit a 5-page report (maximum 10 pages) about their research project in Week 10.  The report should contain an introduction, the methodology, results, and discussions/ideas for future work, written at the level of a popular science book or magazine.  Characteristics that may be considered when marking include: literature review, understanding of the principles, clarity of expression, organisation and soundness of arguments, techniques, presentation of results, suggestion for further work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1867d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8c67d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c467d1bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PHYS1200.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: PHYS1200 is a one-term research project for first-year students.  Students choose from a set of available supervisors and projects, work regularly in the research groups, and present their results to a group of peers and researchers. This course serves as an entry point into physics research for motivated students.

Physics 1B","description":"

This is the second of the two introductory courses in Physics. It is a calculus based course. The course is examined at two levels, with Physics 1A being the lower of the two levels.Electricity and Magnetism: electrostatics, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance and dielectrics, magnetic fields and magnetism, Ampere's and Biot-Savart law, Faraday's law, induction and inductance. Physical Optics: light, interference, diffraction, gratings and spectra, polarization. Introductory quantum theory and the wave nature of matter. Introductory solid state and semiconductor physics: simple energy band picture.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"07bccaf11bf9a010d5fb0fabdc4bcbdc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students complete 9 weekly quizzes at home contributing 10% of their marks. They have two invigilated quizzes each worth 10% in the middle and at the end of semester. These quizzes use a common bank of questions, the at home quizzes give students the opportunity to practice the questions.

Students complete nine laboratry exercises at a rate of one per week. Before each lab the complete a prelab quiz on Moodle. The contributes 2.5% of their total mark for the course (1/8 of their lab mark). Labs are marked during the lab sessions each week. They also conduct a project as a group in the lab during problem solving workshop time. They submit a group report on this and give a presentation. This contributes 10% to their mark.

contentlets.description: This is the second of the two introductory courses in Physics.  It is a calculus based course.  The course is examined at two levels, with Higher Physics 1B being the higher of the two levels.  While the same content is covered as Physics 1B, Higher Physics 1B features more advanced assessment, including separate tutorial and laboratory groups.Electricity and Magnetism: electrostatics, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance and dielectrics, magnetic fields and magnetism, Ampere's and Biot-Savart law, Faraday's law, induction and inductance.  Physical Optics: light, interference, diffraction, gratings and spectra, polarization.  Introductory quantum theory and the wave nature of matter.  Introductory solid state and semiconductor physics: simple energy band picture.
contentlets.title: Higher Physics 1B

Higher Physics 1B (Special)","description":"

This course is designed for Physics majors and all students taking an Advanced Science program that includes Physics. PHYS1241 is the 'companion' course to PHYS1131 Higher Physics 1A or PHYS1141 Higher Physics 1A (Special), available in S1. The topics covered in PHYS1241 are: Electricity and Magnetism: electrostatics, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance and dielectrics, magnetic fields and magnetism, Ampere's and Biot-Savart law, Faraday's law, induction and inductance. Physical Optics: light, interference, diffraction, gratings and spectra, polarization. Introductory quantum theory and the wave of nature of matter. Introductory solid state and semiconductor physics: simple energy band picture. Special relativity: inertial reference frames, length contraction, time dilation, equivalence of mass and energy. There is also a laboratory course covering material relevant to lectures.

Students will complete prework on Moodle before attending the laboratory classes. In the laboratory students will plan and conduct experiments. They will write these up in the supplied laboratory book and submit them for marking three times over the term.

Students will sit a two hour exam during the exam period.

Problems given in the exam will be based on the content from the course, this is described in the learning outcomes.

Students will complete regular online quizzes drawn from a large question bank at home during term with feedback programmed into the quizzes. This will form 10% of their mark. Twice during the semester students will take an invigilated quiz which is drawn from the same question bank. Each of these will form 10% of the total mark for the course.

Quantum mechanics is cornerstone of modern physics, and deals with physical phenomena on microscopic scales.  This  first  course  in  quantum  mechanics will  provide students  with  a  broad  and  comprehensive  introduction  and a foundation  for further study.  Topics to be covered include: Fundamental Constants. Interference. Particle-wave duality. Double-slit experiment. De Broglie relation. Schroedinger Equation. Principle of superposition. Probability and probability current. Copenhagen interpretation. Searches for violation of Quantum Mechanics. Stationary states. Time-independent Schrodinger Equation. Infinite square well. Spectrum and localization. 1D scattering problem. Scattering from finite square well. Notion of deep and shallow level. Bound states in a finite square well. Dirac delta-function. Double well potential with delta functions: Two-level system, Ammonia maser. Harmonic oscillator. General mathematical structure of Quantum Mechanics and formalism. Commutators. Relation to Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Time-dependent Schroedinger Equation. Time dependence of expectation value. Ehrenfest theorem. Semiclassical approximation. Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization.

Student will complete 3 three-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first one to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

Classical mechanics is the study of the motion of objects obeying Newton's laws of motion, while Einstein's special theory of relativity revises the Galilean notion of relativity between inertial frames. This course aims to introduce students to the elegant Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of Newtonian mechanics, and the fundaments of special relativity and the associated 4-formalism. Students will receive a strong grounding in these methods, paving the way for advanced topics in electrodynamics, quantum mechanics, and statistical mechanics. Topics to be covered include: Damped and forced harmonic oscillations and resonance phenomena. Central force problems and celestial orbits. Inertia tensor and rotational dynamics. Variational principles. Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of mechanics. Noether's theorem, symmetry and conservation laws. Coupled oscillators, normal modes, continuous systems and fields. Many-particle systems. Foundations of special relativity. 4-formalism. Lorentz transformation. Spacetime diagrams. Relativistic kinematics and dynamics. Relativistic Doppler effect.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PHYS2114","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHYS2114 - Electromagnetism","description":"

Electromagnetism is important from both fundamental and applied viewpoints. This course aims to provide students with an introduction to the principles and behaviours of electric and magnetic systems, and the unified subject of electromagnetism in terms of Maxwell's four equations. Building on electromagnetic theory, we will analyse a number problems that are of importance in optical and radiofrequency engineering. Topics to be covered include: Electric field and force due to a static electric charge distribution. Electric potential.  Work and energy. Laplace's equation and solution methods. Electric polarisation.  Linear dielectrics. Lorentz force. Magnetic fields due to a steady current distribution. Magnetic vector potential. Magnetization. Linear media. Time-dependent fields. Faraday's law. Inductance. Maxwell's equations. Electromagnetic waves in vacuum. Electromagnetic waves in linear dielectric media.Fresnel reflection at dielectric and metallic interfaces. Electromagnetic waveguide modes. Thin film optics. Polarization states.

Students will sit a 2-hour final exam during the exam period.

Final mark for course given to student

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"18367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"00363cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

An assignment will be handed out to students around [Week 8], based on the materials covered in the course up to that point.  Students will have one week to complete the assignment, which is due in [Week 9].  The assignments will be marked and returned to students within a week.  Solutions will be posted on Moodle when all assignments have been turned in.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"18367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c363cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

A 50-minute in-class test to take place around [Week 4] will examine students on the topics covered in the first few weeks of the lecture course.  The test will be marked, and returned to students within a week.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"18367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c4363cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Student will complete 3 three-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first one to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

Fundamentals of Atmospheric Science","description":"

This course covers the basic physical principles and processes which govern our atmosphere and its climate. First of all, this course provides an introduction and overview of our atmosphere, the main physical principles that govern its behaviour, and how to apply them to important questions about weather and climate. This shows students an important application of basic physics (and a bit of chemistry), and for Oceanography, Meteorology and Climate students this will provide a necessary foundation upon which later courses will build. For instance, you will learn about the ozone hole, the greenhouse effect, how to use charts to determine the likelihood of storms developing, why deserts occur at certain latitudes, and how to use the Bureau of Meteorology’s radar images on its website to track thunderstorms. This course will also train students in how to apply basic principles of physics and mathematics (including calculus) to real-world problems and situations. This skill will add value to the work you have already invested in learning those principles and will be relevant no matter what later path in life you take.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fe9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Continuous quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Every lecture comes with a short online quiz on Moodle. It will give immediate feedback on students' physical understanding of the course material. No derivations or calculations will be needed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"629c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment mid term","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

There is one assessment during the term, which test the students' understanding of the first half of the term. It is made up of several short answer questions which are designed to test students' understanding of key concepts of the course.

Comments and marks from course convener and lab assistants will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b69c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f29c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a9c9dfbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The final exam covers all course content.

Quantum mechanics is a cornerstone of modern physics, and deals with physical phenomena on microscopic scales. This is a highest undergraduate course in quantum mechanics, and will provide students with a broad and comprehensive introduction and a foundation for further study. Topics to be covered include: Quantum mechanics in three dimensions. Angular momentum. Hydrogen atom. Landau levels. Spin. Identical particles and spin-statistic relation. Clebsch-Gordan Coefficients. Time-independent perturbation theory and applications: Particle dynamics in 1D weak sinusoidal potential, band structure, Bloch theorem, Brillouin zone, quasimomentum, metals and band insulators. Time-dependent perturbation theory. Fermi Golden rule. Adiabatic evolution and Berry phase. Particle wave analysis in scattering theory. Born approximation Dispersion relation for scattering amplitude. Low energy and resonance scattering.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3136bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961901","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

An assignment will be handed out to students around [Week 8], based on the materials covered in the course up to that point.  Students will have one week to complete the assignment, which is due in [Week 9].  The assignments will be marked and returned to students within a week.  Solutions will be posted on Moodle when all assignments have been turned in.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b9367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will complete 2 four-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first one to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"35367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will sit a 2-hour final exam during the exam period.

Final grade will be given to student

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7d367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b9367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a5367cb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

A 50-minute in-class test to take place around [Week 4] will examine students on the topics covered in the first few weeks of the lecture course.  The test will be marked, and returned to students within a week.

This course will provide the skills and knowledge required to investigate, both experimentally and computationally, a wide range of physical phenomena. The course consists of both lecture and laboratory classes, covering topics such as statistical analysis of data, sampling and information theory, numerical solutions of ordinary differential equations, Fourier transform theory and discrete Fourier transform, spectroscopy, handling and numerical modelling of noise and stochastic processes, inverse problems, experimental control, nonlinear systems, and quantum measurements.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9736bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Student will complete 9 four-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1336bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5f36bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9b36bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d336bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f36bcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will sit a 2-hour final exam during the exam period.

Final mark will be given to student.

Two assignments will be handed out to students around [Week 3] and [Week 8], based on the materials covered in the course up to that point.  Students will have one week to complete the assignments, due respectively in [Week 4] and [Week 9].  The assignments will be marked and returned to students within a week.  Solutions will be posted on Moodle when all assignments have been turned in.

Thermal physics and statistical mechanics is concerned with the study of macroscopic and mesoscopic systems.  Both aim to understand the properties of systems and processes that occur in such systems. Statistical mechanics links mesoscopic and macroscopic properties of systems of matter and radiation with the fundamental microscopic physics (classical and quantum mechanics).  It puts the concepts of thermodynamics on a firm foundation of  mechanics.  Its importance in the development of modern physics, from  the  understanding  of stars to the smallest transistor, cannot be overestimated.  Topics to be covered include: Classical thermodynamics. Kinetic theory of gases, ideal gas, van der Waals gas. First law of thermodynamics.  Heat engines, Carnot cycle, Carnot’s theorem.  Classical entropy, second law of thermodynamics. Third law of thermodynamics. Postulate approach to classical thermodynamics, fundamental 1° equation and its consequences. Alternative formulations, thermodynamic potentials, Legendre transforms, Maxwell’s relations. Phase transitions stability criteria, Clausius-Clapeyron equation, Gibbs phase rule. Thermodynamic probability, Boltzmann entropy. Boltzmann distribution, Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions. Partition function. Micro-canonical, canonical and grand canonical ensembles. Heat capacity of diatomics, Einstein and Debye models, phonons. Paramagnetism. Blackbody radiation. Bose-Einstein condensation, liquid helium. Fermi energy, free electrons and the Fermi gas.

Classical electrodynamics is important from both the fundamental and applied viewpoints.  This course aims to provide students with an introduction to the principles and behaviours of dynamical electric and magnetic systems, and a theoretical foundation in classical field theory.  The course will begin with the application of electromagnetic theory to study optical phenomena, before moving on to more formal topics.  It will finish with an introduction to relativistic electrodynamics and its covariant formulation, paving the way for a quantum field theory of electrodynamics (QED).  Topics to be covered include: Scalar diffraction theory. Image formation and Fourier Optics, Coherence. Electromagnetic fields in dispersive media. Scattering. Maxwell’s equations potential formulation. Gauge transformation. Poynting’s theorem, conservation laws. Green’s function solution of static problems. Inhomogeneous wave equation and Green’s function solution. Dipole radiation. Emission of radiation from accelerating and decelerating charges. Relativistic electrodynamics. Covariant formulation.

An assignment will be handed out to students around [Week 8], based on the materials covered in the course up to that point.  Students will have one week to complete the assignment, which is due in [Week 9].  The assignments will be marked and returned to students within a week.  Solutions will be posted on Moodle when all assignments have been turned in.

A 50-minute in-class test to take place around [Week 4] will examine students on the topics covered in the first few weeks of the lecture course.  The test will be marked, and returned to students within a week.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0046fcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4c46fcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f336fcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ab36fcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Student will complete 2 four-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first one to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

This course aims to provide an introduction to modern elementary particle physics from both an experimental and theoretical viewpoint, and how particle physics impacts on the structure and chemical composition of the universe. Topics to be covered include: Basic ideas of the standard model. Interaction and fields. Feynman diagrams. Yukawa theory. Cross section and decay rates. Accelerators and particle detectors. Invariance principle and conservation laws: parity, charge conjugation, time reversal, CPT. Quark model of hadron structure. Concepts of QCD and asymptotic freedom. Concepts of electroweak theory, Higgs mechanism. CP violation. Neutrino oscillations. FLRW universe: thermal history, particle decoupling. Big bang nucleosynthesis. Boltzmann equation in an FLRW universe: WIMP freeze-out, baryogensis, recombination and photon decoupling. Phase transitions. Inflation: scalar field models, Klein-Gordon equation, inflation fluctuations as seeds for structure formation. Particle physics impact on the cosmic microwave background and structure formation. Particle dark matter models. Dark matter direct and indirect detection. Dark energy and scalar field models.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b846fcb7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar presentation and peer review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Students, in teams of two, will present a 20-minute seminar each on a topic in modern particle physics assigned to them by the lecturer.  Students will also provide anonymous peer review on each other’s seminars.  Marks are assigned on the basis of the quality of the presentation, delivery, and scientific content of the seminar, and on the constructiveness of the peer review feedback.

contentlets.description: This course aims to provide an introduction to modern elementary particle physics from both an experimental and theoretical viewpoint, and how particle physics impacts on the structure and chemical composition of the universe. Topics to be covered include: Basic ideas of the standard model. Interaction and fields. Feynman diagrams. Yukawa theory. Cross section and decay rates. Accelerators and particle detectors. Invariance principle and conservation laws: parity, charge conjugation, time reversal, CPT. Quark model of hadron structure. Concepts of QCD and asymptotic freedom. Concepts of electroweak theory, Higgs mechanism. CP violation. Neutrino oscillations. FLRW universe: thermal history, particle decoupling. Big bang nucleosynthesis. Boltzmann equation in an FLRW universe: WIMP freeze-out, baryogensis, recombination and photon decoupling. Phase transitions. Inflation: scalar field models, Klein-Gordon equation, inflation fluctuations as seeds for structure formation. Particle physics impact on the cosmic microwave background and structure formation. Particle dark matter models. Dark matter direct and indirect detection. Dark energy and scalar field models.
contentlets.title: Particle Physics and the Early Universe

The stars form the basic building blocks of our Galaxy, and make up one of the fundamental scales on which structure is found in the Universe.  This course provides an introduction to the physics of stars, galaxies and the universe.  The aim is to give students an introduction to our state of knowledge about these fundamental astronomical objects, what they contain, their physical parameters, how they function and how they evolve. The basic mathematical formalism governing the physics of is presented, though the detailed solution of the equations is not attempted.  Topics to be covered include: Galaxies, their composition. The distance scale. Large-scale structure of the universe. Galaxy evolution. Stellar radiation, spectra classification. Hertzsprung Russell diagrams, determination of stellar masses and radii.  Equations of stellar structure. Energy sources in star: nuclear reaction cycles, energy transport, equations of state, degeneracy, opacity. Properties of main sequence stars: stellar evolution, structure of red giants and white dwarfs. The solar atmosphere.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PHYS3118","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHYS3118 - Quantum Physics of Solids and Devices","description":"


Quantum mechanics plays an important role in the properties of solids, and will be central to new generations of
electronic devices across the coming decades, e.g., quantum computers. Existing devices, such as laser diodes and superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs), also exploit quantum phenomena for their operation. This course covers three main areas. The first is 'The Quantum Physics of Solids', with topics including crystal structure, phonons as quantum oscillations, electrons as quantum particles in solids, band structure and unconventional materials. The second is 'Interactions in Quantum Systems', with topics including paramagnetism, diamagnetism and ferromagnetism, electron-electron interactions and their role in screening and plasmonic effects, and superconductivity. The third is 'From Semiconductors to Quantum Devices', with topics including charge carriers in semiconductors, p-n junctions and diodes, finite solids and heterojunctions, quantum confinement and low-dimensional devices, nanoelectronics. The course will appeal to those seeking a better contextual understanding of quantum mechanics and to learn about its real world applications: past, present and future.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"034670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961932","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

An assignment will be handed out to students around [Week 8], based on the materials covered in the course up to that point.  Students will have one week to complete the assignment, which is due in [Week 9].  The assignments will be marked and returned to students within a week.  Solutions will be posted on Moodle when all assignments have been turned in.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"364670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba4670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f64670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a4670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Student will complete 3 four-hour laboratory experiments over the term, the first one to be scheduled within the first three weeks of the term.  Assessments will be based on the written account and accompanying interview with an academic marker in the week after the experiment.  Marks will be allocated based on (i) an understanding of the underlying physical principles, (ii) the quality of the experimental results and analysis, and (iii) the presentation of the lab book.  Feedback is provided on the same day as the interview.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"364670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f64670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"624670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will sit a 2-hour final exam during the exam period.

Final course grade will be given to student

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"364670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba4670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f64670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa4670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

A 50-minute in-class test to take place around [Week 4] will examine students on the topics covered in the first few weeks of the lecture course.  The test will be marked, and returned to students within a week.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"364670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba4670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f64670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e24670f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PHYS3118.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Quantum mechanics plays an important role in the properties of solids, and will be central to new generations of
electronic devices across the coming decades, e.g., quantum computers. Existing devices, such as laser diodes and superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs), also exploit quantum phenomena for their operation. This course covers three main areas. The first is 'The Quantum Physics of Solids', with topics including crystal structure, phonons as quantum oscillations, electrons as quantum particles in solids, band structure and unconventional materials. The second is 'Interactions in Quantum Systems', with topics including paramagnetism, diamagnetism and ferromagnetism, electron-electron interactions and their role in screening and plasmonic effects, and superconductivity. The third is 'From Semiconductors to Quantum Devices', with topics including charge carriers in semiconductors, p-n junctions and diodes, finite solids and heterojunctions, quantum confinement and low-dimensional devices, nanoelectronics. The course will appeal to those seeking a better contextual understanding of quantum mechanics and to learn about its real world applications: past, present and future.

This advanced Quantum Mechanics course is designed to provide students with a solid foundation needed to understand relativistic quantum mechanics, quantum electrodynamics, the standard model, and quantum information and computation. Topics include: The spin-statistics relationship; second quantisation; angular momentum; the density matrix; relaxation and decoherence; the Klein-Gordon equation; the Dirac equation; second quantisation of the Dirac field.

In this Honours course, students will be introduced to concepts and methods in advanced statistical physics which will allow them to understand a wide range of effects encountered in many-body systems.  The course will cover the subjects of mean field theory, phase transitions, critical phenomena, the physics of non-equilibrium processes as well as a selection of more specialized topics.

Students will take two of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.


Quantum Matter, Information and Computing will introduce students to quantum computing, the physics of superconducting devices, the Quantum Hall and other topological effects in materials, and the basics of Fermi liquid theory. Advanced topics will include Andreev scattering at semiconductor-superconductor interfaces and Majorana fermions, fractional quantum Hall effect, graphene and the two-dimensional Dirac equation.

The Advanced Astrophysics module develops in-depth knowledge of topics in modern Astrophysics and equips students with a modern toolset to engage in cutting-edge research.  Students obtain a core understanding of the physics of relevant equations and develop fundamental physics intuition.  Topics include: radiative transfer; exoplanets; asteroseismology; interstellar medium and star formation; galaxy formation and evolution; cosmology; time-domain astrophysics; statistical techniques.


Quantum field theory is an important tool in many branches of theoretical physics.  In fundamental physics, the QFT framework combines special relativity and quantum mechanics to explain the subatomic structure of matter and the physics of the early universe.   In condensed matter physics, it provides a quantum description of many-body systems.  This first course in QFT comprises an introduction to classical field theory, the Euler-Lagrange equations and Noether’s theorem, the Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations, the quantisation of free scalar, vector and spinor fields; and a selection of topics drawn from covariant perturbation theory, the S-matrix and Feynman diagrams; the computation of elementary processes in quantum electrodynamics; field theory approach to phase transitions; dimensional reduction in classical criticality;  critical indexes in low-dimensional systems; non-linear sigma-model and topological solutions.


The General Theory of Relativity is Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation that unifies the Special Theory of Relativity and Newton’s law of gravitation.  This first course in General Relativity will provide an introduction to non-Euclidean geometry, Einstein’s equation; spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein’s equations (Schwarzschild solution), the weak field limit; Gravitational collapse, black holes; linearised gravity, gravitational waves and their production and observation; Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker cosmology, the standard hot Big Bang model.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"63b18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961994","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Two final exams (one for each topic). Each will be a 2 hour closed book exam, which will contribute 30% to the final grade. Each exam will consist of a number of quantative problems relating to the theory and applications of Quantum Field Theory; General Relativity; Astrophysics; and/or Quantum Matter.
Student advised of marks

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9fb18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbb18977db391c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03b18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal Club","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Each student will be assigned a paper (the papers will represent key advances in physics that will be of interest to any serious physicist.). They will make a 20 minute presentation that covers the background, the advance and its implications. Every member of the class will be expected to at least read the paper. The presenter will then lead a discussion (~20 minutes) of the work.

\n

Students will be marked by predefined crieria on their presentation and participation, and given feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1bb18977db391c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"57b18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9fb18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8fb18977db391c50eb6b147a3a961968","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Four quantitative assignments, worth 30% in total (two assignments worth 15% per topic). Each assignment should require a maximum of 10 hours out-of-class work to complete.
Marked assignments returned with comments

contentlets.description:
Students will take two of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.

Quantum Matter, Information and Computing will introduce students to quantum computing, the physics of superconducting devices, the Quantum Hall and other topological effects in materials, and the basics of Fermi liquid theory. Advanced topics will include Andreev scattering at semiconductor-superconductor interfaces and Majorana fermions, fractional quantum Hall effect, graphene and the two-dimensional Dirac equation.

The Advanced Astrophysics module develops in-depth knowledge of topics in modern Astrophysics and equips students with a modern toolset to engage in cutting-edge research.  Students obtain a core understanding of the physics of relevant equations and develop fundamental physics intuition.  Topics include: radiative transfer; exoplanets; asteroseismology; interstellar medium and star formation; galaxy formation and evolution; cosmology; time-domain astrophysics; statistical techniques.

Quantum field theory is an important tool in many branches of theoretical physics.  In fundamental physics, the QFT framework combines special relativity and quantum mechanics to explain the subatomic structure of matter and the physics of the early universe.   In condensed matter physics, it provides a quantum description of many-body systems.  This first course in QFT comprises an introduction to classical field theory, the Euler-Lagrange equations and Noether’s theorem, the Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations, the quantisation of free scalar, vector and spinor fields; and a selection of topics drawn from covariant perturbation theory, the S-matrix and Feynman diagrams; the computation of elementary processes in quantum electrodynamics; field theory approach to phase transitions; dimensional reduction in classical criticality;  critical indexes in low-dimensional systems; non-linear sigma-model and topological solutions.

The General Theory of Relativity is Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation that unifies the Special Theory of Relativity and Newton’s law of gravitation.  This first course in General Relativity will provide an introduction to non-Euclidean geometry, Einstein’s equation; spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein’s equations (Schwarzschild solution), the weak field limit; Gravitational collapse, black holes; linearised gravity, gravitational waves and their production and observation; Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker cosmology, the standard hot Big Bang model.

Students in this course undertake a full year research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Physics. Taken in combination with PHYS4145 Physics Honours Research B and PHYS4146 Physics Honours Research C this course will contribute towards the 24 UOC of research required in the Physics Honours stream at UNSW.

Students will be required to submit a research proposal, a literature review, and a final thesis. Students will be required to present a seminar at the end of their research, which will not contribute to their final mark but is a compulsory component of the degree.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the Physics Honours stream in the Faculty of Science.

As students complete a full-year project, the marks for the three research subjects will be identical, calculated from the research proposal, literature review and final thesis.

In this course students will undertake a one-term research project supervised by an academic staff member in one of our research groups.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fba95537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will give a 5-minute talk each at the end of the teaching term (around Week 10) about their research project, including aims, a brief description of the methodology, results, and conclusions.  The presentation will be marked based on the clarity of explanation of the project aims, quality of the presentation, relevance of the results, and delivery.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fba91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ffa95537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27a91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will conduct a research project under the supervision of a member of the academic staff.  The project may involve conducting experiments in the laboratory, analysis of data from observations, theoretical calculations, or some combination of the above. At the end of the project, a mark will be given by their supervisor on their research performance.  Some charateristics the supevisor may wish to assess include: the student's approach to the problem, preparatory reading, planning of experimental work, design of apparatus, independence, execution of the research, diligence, understanding of the principles, experimental technique, judgment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fba91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ffa95537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27a91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will submit a 10-page report (maximum 20 pages) about their research project in Week 10.  The report should contain an introduction, the methodoloy, results, and discussions/ideas for future work, written for an intelligent but non-expert audience.  Characterisitcs that may be considered when marking include: literature review, understnading of the principles, clarity of expression, organisation and soundness of arguments, techniques, presentation of results, suggestion for further work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fba91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ffa95537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6fa91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will submit a maximum 5-page literature review, including references, in relation to their research project.  The review will be marked on the basis of the clarity of explanation of the project aims and place in the field of research, as well as the relevance of the references.  The report is due in week 4, marked and then returned to students along with feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fba91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eba91537db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PHYS4200.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Students will take one of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.


Quantum Matter, Information and Computing will introduce students to quantum computing, the physics of superconducting devices, the Quantum Hall and other topological effects in materials, and the basics of Fermi liquid theory. Advanced topics will include Andreev scattering at semiconductor-superconductor interfaces and Majorana fermions, fractional quantum Hall effect, graphene and the two-dimensional Dirac equation.

The Advanced Astrophysics module develops in-depth knowledge of topics in modern Astrophysics and equips students with a modern toolset to engage in cutting-edge research.  Students obtain a core understanding of the physics of relevant equations and develop fundamental physics intuition.  Topics include: radiative transfer; exoplanets; asteroseismology; interstellar medium and star formation; galaxy formation and evolution; cosmology; time-domain astrophysics; statistical techniques.


Quantum field theory is an important tool in many branches of theoretical physics.  In fundamental physics, the QFT framework combines special relativity and quantum mechanics to explain the subatomic structure of matter and the physics of the early universe.   In condensed matter physics, it provides a quantum description of many-body systems.  This first course in QFT comprises an introduction to classical field theory, the Euler-Lagrange equations and Noether’s theorem, the Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations, the quantisation of free scalar, vector and spinor fields; and a selection of topics drawn from covariant perturbation theory, the S-matrix and Feynman diagrams; the computation of elementary processes in quantum electrodynamics; field theory approach to phase transitions; dimensional reduction in classical criticality;  critical indexes in low-dimensional systems; non-linear sigma-model and topological solutions.


The General Theory of Relativity is Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation that unifies the Special Theory of Relativity and Newton’s law of gravitation.  This first course in General Relativity will provide an introduction to non-Euclidean geometry, Einstein’s equation; spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein’s equations (Schwarzschild solution), the weak field limit; Gravitational collapse, black holes; linearised gravity, gravitational waves and their production and observation; Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker cosmology, the standard hot Big Bang model.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5053c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c53c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0453c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

A a 2 hour closed book exam, which will contribute 60% to the final grade. The exam will consist of a number of quantative problems relating to the theory and applications of Quantum Field Theory; General Relativity; Astrophysics; and/or Quantum Matter.
Student advised of marks

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5053c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c53c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c53c97bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will take one of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.

Quantum Matter, Information and Computing will introduce students to quantum computing, the physics of superconducting devices, the Quantum Hall and other topological effects in materials, and the basics of Fermi liquid theory. Advanced topics will include Andreev scattering at semiconductor-superconductor interfaces and Majorana fermions, fractional quantum Hall effect, graphene and the two-dimensional Dirac equation.

The Advanced Astrophysics module develops in-depth knowledge of topics in modern Astrophysics and equips students with a modern toolset to engage in cutting-edge research.  Students obtain a core understanding of the physics of relevant equations and develop fundamental physics intuition.  Topics include: radiative transfer; exoplanets; asteroseismology; interstellar medium and star formation; galaxy formation and evolution; cosmology; time-domain astrophysics; statistical techniques.

Quantum field theory is an important tool in many branches of theoretical physics.  In fundamental physics, the QFT framework combines special relativity and quantum mechanics to explain the subatomic structure of matter and the physics of the early universe.   In condensed matter physics, it provides a quantum description of many-body systems.  This first course in QFT comprises an introduction to classical field theory, the Euler-Lagrange equations and Noether’s theorem, the Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations, the quantisation of free scalar, vector and spinor fields; and a selection of topics drawn from covariant perturbation theory, the S-matrix and Feynman diagrams; the computation of elementary processes in quantum electrodynamics; field theory approach to phase transitions; dimensional reduction in classical criticality;  critical indexes in low-dimensional systems; non-linear sigma-model and topological solutions.

The General Theory of Relativity is Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation that unifies the Special Theory of Relativity and Newton’s law of gravitation.  This first course in General Relativity will provide an introduction to non-Euclidean geometry, Einstein’s equation; spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein’s equations (Schwarzschild solution), the weak field limit; Gravitational collapse, black holes; linearised gravity, gravitational waves and their production and observation; Friedmann-Lemaitre-Robertson-Walker cosmology, the standard hot Big Bang model.
