","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PHYS9010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHYS9010 - Quantum Technologies and Applications","description":"

This course aims to provide a framework to explore past, present and future developments of Quantum Technologies as a young, but fast-growing industry. The course will also help you gain foundational understanding of central concepts and principles underlying Quantum Technologies and their real-world applications.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4960bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Three online tests (each worth 10%) evaluating knowledge of quantum mechanics and their links to latest developments and emerging technologies in the field of Quantum Technologies.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2060bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment task has 2 parts: completion of a portfolio comprising 4 technical digests (20%), and peer review of 3 technical digests (15%).

Portfolio of technical digests

You are required to create a portfolio that is made up of a technical digest for each of the main branches of Quantum Technologies: Quantum Sensors, Quantum Communication, Quantum Simulations, and Quantum Computing. The technical digests focus on answering big-picture questions covered in the course and on explaining, in your own words, the underlying quantum mechanical concepts and effects to further develop your technical understanding and ability to communicate this.

 

At the end of the course, you will submit your portfolio (electronically).

 

Peer review of 3 technical digests

You will be required to upload one of your technical digests and will be randomly assigned with 3 technical digests from your peers to review. Using the Peer Review rubric, you will review your peers’ work and offer feedback for improvement. There will be clear instructions to help you apply the rubric and provide constructive and meaningful feedback. You will be marked by your peers on the quality of your review and feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0160bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4d60bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b460bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f060bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6860bdffdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quantum Technology Deep Dive","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment task has 2 parts: completion of a piece that is Deep Dive into a Quantum Technology (25%), and peer feedback on 2 Deep Dive pieces (10%).

 

Deep Dive piece

In this final assessment task, you will write about a particular Quantum Technology of your choice. The Deep Dive is an extended piece that explains and critiques a current or proposed device, company, idea, or application in Quantum Technology. It should contain technical descriptions and broader evaluations and discussions of the purpose and intended impact of your chosen focus, as well as comparisons with existing devices, companies, ideas, or applications. The Deep Dive should also feature a description of the industrial and social context. You are free to choose your own topic based on what is of interest or relevance to your own work, but the topic must be approved by the course convener.

 

Peer feedback on 2 Deep Dive pieces

Prior to finalising and submitting your piece, you will give and receive feedback from your peers to help each other improve the Deep Dive pieces. You will be required to offer feedback for improvement, and will be peer marked on the quality of your feedback.

The course will also help you gain foundational understanding of central concepts and principles underlying Quantum Technologies and their real-world applications.

Everyday Physics for Teachers","description":"

This is a fully online course that looks at the physics behind common objects. Physics topics addressed in this course include basic mechanics, properties of waves, Archimedes principle and fluid flow. Basic experimental methods will be covered through simulations and simple experiments that can be conducted at home. The course is aimed at qualified science teachers. It serves as the introductory unit in the Graduate Certificate in Physics for Science Teachers.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9f000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961928","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This will involve coming up with an experiment that students could conduct in a high school class room setting to demonstrate the physics behind some everyday phenomenon. Students will submit a draft of their final report through the workshop (peer review) tool on Moodle to get feedback from their peers. The feedback they give to their peers will form 10% of their course mark. The remaining 20% will come from the final version of their report that they will submit through Turnitin. This will be marked by tutors according to a rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"57000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"93000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reports submitted for simple experiments and simulations conducted at home.","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

These will be submitted fortnightly through Turnitin in Moodle. They will be marked with a rubric by tutors. For each investigation students will be given or will need to write a risk assessment before commencing work. This will ensure students learn about managing risks as well as keeping them safe while they complete their experimental work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"57000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"93000573db391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0700c173db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This will be an invigilated examination at the end of the course. With prior consent students outside of Sydney can have this invigilated at another location (eg. as the students are school teachers their principal could invigilate it). It is the student's responsibility to make appropriate arrangements and to then get these approved by the course convener well in advance of the final examination.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b000573db391c50eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db000573db391c50eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f00c173db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PHYS9110.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Mechanics for Teachers","description":"

This is an online course covering mechanics. Lecture material and tutorial problems will be presented online. This is the second course in the graduate certificate for physics teachers. The course will cover classical Newtonian mechanics and special relativity. Classical mechanics is used to describe the motion of bodies under a system of forces. Special relativity is needed to describe the motion of bodies traveling with high speeds. Students will watch short video lectures online and solve problems related to the material. This course includes laboratory exercises that are completed at home and submitted online.


Assumed Knowledge: Students need to be able to differentiate and integrate polynomials to complete this courses. A good understanding of HSC level extension 1 mathematics is recommended.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8e17a1f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This will be an invigilated examination at the end of the course. With prior consent students outside of Sydney can have this invigilated at another location (eg. as the students are school teachers their principal could invigilate it). It is the student's responsibility to make appropriate arrangements and to then get these approved by the course convener well in advance of the final examination.

Four laboratory experiments will be carried out during the course. These will involve students using standard high school laboratory equipment or everyday items to conduct an experiment. Experimental reports will be uploaded to Turnitin through Moodle for marking. At the end of the course students will submit a report on one of the experiments, showing how it could be adapted for use in a high school classroom, this will be marked by the course convener or tutors.

contentlets.description:
This is an online course covering mechanics. Lecture material and tutorial problems will be presented online. This is the second course in the graduate certificate for physics teachers. The course will cover classical Newtonian mechanics and special relativity. Classical mechanics is used to describe the motion of bodies under a system of forces. Special relativity is needed to describe the motion of bodies traveling with high speeds. Students will watch short video lectures online and solve problems related to the material. This course includes laboratory exercises that are completed at home and submitted online.

Assumed Knowledge: Students need to be able to differentiate and integrate polynomials to complete this courses. A good understanding of HSC level extension 1 mathematics is recommended.
contentlets.title: Mechanics for Teachers

Electromagnetism for Teachers","description":"

This is an online course covering electromagnetism. Lecture material and tutorial problems will be presented online. This is the third course in the graduate certificate for physics teachers. This course will teach students about electromagnetism. Electromagnetism is the branch of physics concerned with studying interactions between electrically charged particles. In this course students will learn about electrical circuits containing resistors, capacitors and inductors. They will use Gauss's law to find electric fields and electric potentials around symmetric charge distributions. They will learn how to define and calculate capacitance. The course will also look at magnetic fields and magnetic inductance. Electromagnetic waves and optics will be considered. This course includes laboratory exercises that are completed at home and submitted online.


Assumed Knowledge: Students need to be able to differentiate and integrate polynomials to complete this course. A good understanding of HSC level extension 1 mathematics is recommended.

This course will teach students about electromagnetism. Electromagnetism is the branch of physics concerned with studying interactions between electrically charged particles. In this course students will learn about electrical circuits containing resistors, capacitors and inductors. They will use Gauss's law to find electric fields and electric potentials around symmetric charge distributions. They will learn how to define and calculate capacitance. The course will also look at magnetic fields and magnetic inductance. Electromagnetic waves and optics will be considered. This course includes laboratory exercises that are completed at home and submitted online.

Assumed Knowledge: Students need to be able to differentiate and integrate polynomials to complete this course. A good understanding of HSC level extension 1 mathematics is recommended.
contentlets.title: Electromagnetism for Teachers

This is an online course covering thermal and modern physics. Lecture material and tutorial problems will be presented online. This is the fourth course in the graduate certificate for physics teachers. This course will cover thermal physics, and introduce quantum mechanics including the Schrodinger equation for simple situations, the standard model will be discussed and applications of quantum mechanics considered. This course includes laboratory exercises that are completed at home and submitted online.


Assumed knowledge:  Students need to be able to differentiate and integrate polynomials and write and solve simple differential equations to complete the course. A good understanding of HSC level extension 1 mathematics is recommended.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f67bf477dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961938","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiments","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Four laboratory experiments will be carried out during the course. These will involve students using standard high school laboratory equipment or everyday items to conduct an experiment. Experimental reports will be uploaded to Turnitin through Moodle for marking. At the end of the course students will submit a report on one of the experiments, showing how it could be adapted for use in a high school classroom, this will be marked by the course convener or tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"fa7bf477dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e7bf477dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This will be an invigilated examination at the end of the course. With prior consent students outside of Sydney can have this invigilated at another location (eg. as the students are school teachers their principal could invigilate it). It is the student's responsibility to make appropriate arrangements and to then get these approved by the course convener well in advance of the final examination.
